Read OMNI-2 hourly data files for 2023 and 2024 with fixed field-widths.
Convert the year, day-of-year and hour columns of OMNI-2 into a timezone-aware (UTC) DateTimeIndex, sort chronologically and use it as the time index.
Load every 2024 Swarm-B POD neutral-density text file: skip '#' comment lines, read whitespace-delimited fields, build a time index from the date & time columns (UTC).
Keep only the Swarm-B records that occur exactly on the hour (minute = 0, second = 0, microsecond = 0) so they can be matched to the hourly OMNI-2 data.

For any requested model time, derive NRLMSISE-00 driving parameters directly from the indexed OMNI-2 dataframe:
    • daily Ap = mean of the 24 hourly Ap values of that day,
    • F10.7 = the 00:00 UT row of that day,
    • F10.7A = 81-day running mean of daily F10.7 ending the previous day (skip model run when the 81-day window is incomplete),
    • 3-hour Ap vector (length 7) generated from the mean Ap of consecutive 3-h bins according to the MATLAB/NRLMSISE specification.

For each hourly Swarm-B measurement, build the MSIS input set from OMNI-2 (skip hours with missing OMNI or missing F10.7A), extract satellite geodetic latitude, longitude and altitude (convert altitude to km).
Feed these inputs to a custom wrapper around the NRLMSISE-00 (gtd7 / gtd7d) model to obtain the modeled mass density ρ for that epoch.
Collect modeled densities and observed Swarm-B densities in parallel NumPy arrays.
After processing the full year, compute the root-mean-square error: RMSE = sqrt(mean((pred − obs)²)) over all retained hours.
Print the resulting RMSE value, which quantifies NRLMSISE-00 performance against Swarm-B neutral-density observations for 2024.
